normalised: Telecommunications: Fiber to Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India

unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty six - Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel are aggressively expanding their Fiber to Home (F T T H) infrastructure across India, aiming to connect millions of households with high speed broadband. The companies are focusing on tier two and tier three cities, including Lucknow and Patna, to bridge the digital divide.

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 - Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel are aggressively expanding their Fiber-to-Home (FTTH) infrastructure across India, aiming to connect millions of households with high-speed broadband. The companies are focusing on tier-2 and tier-3 cities, including Lucknow and Patna, to bridge the digital divide.
normalised: Doctor Rajesh Kumar, a telecommunications analyst at I I T Delhi, notes, "F T T H is crucial for supporting India's burgeoning digital economy, enabling e-commerce, online education, and remote work."

unnormalised: Dr. Rajesh Kumar, a telecommunications analyst at IIT Delhi, notes, "FTTH is crucial for supporting India's burgeoning digital economy, enabling e-commerce, online education, and remote work."
normalised: Bharti Airtel recently announced plans to extend its fiber network by fifty thousand kilometer in the next fiscal year, investing rupee ten thousand crore. Jio, on the other hand, is focusing on dense urban areas, offering bundled services including I P T V.

unnormalised: Bharti Airtel recently announced plans to extend its fiber network by 50,000 km in the next fiscal year, investing Rs. 10,000 Crore. Jio, on the other hand, is focusing on dense urban areas, offering bundled services including IPTV.
normalised: Analysts predict that the demand for F T T H will continue to surge as more Indians embrace digital services. The average Indian household, with a typical area of one thousand two hundred square feet, can greatly benefit from faster and more reliable internet connectivity. Further expansion is expected, driven by government initiatives and private sector investment.

unnormalised: Analysts predict that the demand for FTTH will continue to surge as more Indians embrace digital services. The average Indian household, with a typical area of 1,200 sq ft, can greatly benefit from faster and more reliable internet connectivity. Further expansion is expected, driven by government initiatives and private sector investment.
